section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce the vocabulary (give thanks, harvest).
Begin story time by introducing the book and asking, What foods come from farms?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Talk and share.
Identify and solve problems.
Persist in tasks.
Make predictions.
Separate syllables from a word.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g. food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify whether the person in the picture is a farmer.
Guide students to speak in complex sentences and use social studies words.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What foods do you see in that book?
What kind of food can you pretend to eat?
What is a cup for? What is a spoon for?
What foods can you draw? What colors would you use?
What can you use to make pretend food? What color will you choose?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of eat?
Can you use blocks to build a farm? What buildings does a farm have?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder follow rules and routines, engage the children with the theme song, and introduce the vocabulary (routine, share).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Before We Eat.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of conversational partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Follow classroom rules and routines
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Make inferences.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children identify rules and routines of the classroom.
Guide students to answer questions and have conversations about routines.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me someone following a rule or routine in this book?
Can you pretend to follow a routine? What routine would you like to act out?
Show me how to bake something. How would you measure things you need?
Make a list of your rules at home.
Can you make a farm? What colors would you use?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of routine?
How would you build a chicken coop?

Text copyright © 2014, 2018 by Pat Brisson. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary Azarian. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Tilbury House Publishers. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make an Inference, and introduce the vocabulary (fields, plowed).
Begin story time by introducing the book Before We Eat and asking, How do farmers and workers get food to your dinner table?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of conversational partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use a growing number of common phrases; Understand and use a growing number of social studies words.
Identify and solve problems
Persist in tasks.
Make inferences.
Use digital tools and resources safely; Show understanding of common technology and how it affects how people live.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Engage students in a question-and-answer session about problems and solutions.
Guide students to identify problems and solutions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is the problem in this story? How can you solve the problem?
Pretend you are having a disagreement about what to eat for lunch. How would you solve the problem?
Can you name a food that is split up into more than one piece so everyone can have some?
Can you draw a machine that can help you do something?
Make a machine used for cooking.
How do you make the letter T, for technology?
What can you use to build a delivery truck?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson, illustrated by Mary Azarian. Text copyright © 2014, 2018 by Pat Brisson. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary Azarian. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Tilbury House Publishers.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Let’s Make Fruit Salad!

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about their bodies and introduce the vocabulary (fruit salad, ingredients).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Let’s Make Fruit Salad! and Before We Eat.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings words and phrases in a language other than their own.
Follow oral directions.

Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe places, things, and action; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases; Understand and use a growing number of social studies words.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Make connections between situations.
Make inferences.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach children the features of fruits.
Challenge children to guess whether a food is a fruit or not.
Practice sorting and classifying the foods/fruits.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What are people making to eat in this book?
Pretend you are making a vegetable salad. What ingredients will you use?
Can you put these fruits in order from largest to smallest?
Can you draw a picture of you eating your least favorite food?
Make your favorite pretend food.
What letters make the oo sound in food?
Think about how you could build a refrigerator out of blocks. What are the first foods you would you put in it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson, illustrated by Mary Azarian. Text copyright © 2014, 2018 by Pat Brisson. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary Azarian. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Tilbury House Publishers.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out a food-related job, sing a song, and introduce the vocabulary words (sorted, clerks).
Begin story time by revisiting the book Before We Eat and asking, If you could have any job in this book, which job would it be?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding; differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of social studies words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Compose an informative text; Share and celebrate written products.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to the week’s prompt: Write about a farmer. What kinds of food does the farmer grow?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Display children’s writings in Sleeved Booklets.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine you wrote a book about your favorite food. What would you put in it?
Pretend to be a clerk in a store.
Can you line up all the fruit and measure how long the line is using counters?
What are some words that rhyme with food?
Can you invent a food no one has ever seen before? What materials will you use?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word restaurant?
Can you work together to build a restaurant? What will you use for tables?

Text copyright © 2014, 2018 by Pat Brisson. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary Azarian. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Tilbury House Publishers.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Engage in various forms of nonverbal communication with those who do not speak their native language.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Talk and share.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Segment a syllable from a word.
Show that people need food and shelter.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Follow classroom rules and routines with reminders from teacher.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Connect their lives to events, time, and routines.
Engage in conversation in appropriate ways.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Practice safe behavior while using digital tools and resources.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Engage in conversation in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe things.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Engage in various forms of nonverbal communication with those who do not speak their native language.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Make connections between situations.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write or draw to communicate ideas.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
